choices.D: System class name, Fully qualified domain name, IP or MAC address
choices.A: CI name, Fully qualified domain name, IP or MAC address
choices.B: CI name, Webserver name, IP or MAC address
choices.C: CI name, Fully qualified domain name, SSH public host keys

questions.question_text: By default, Event Management tries to bind an alert to CI (configuration item), by matching the node name in the event to which three items in the CMDB (configuration management database)?
The MID Server requires an outbound connection on which port?
If more than one event rule applies to a particular event or metric, which of the event rules will run based upon the Order of execution number?

choices.D: All event rules will run, from the highest to the lowest Order of execution numbers.
choices.B: Only the event rule with the lowest Order of execution number will run.
choices.C: All event rules will run, from the lowest to the highest Order of execution numbers.
choices.A: Only the event rule with the highest Order of execution number will run.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The question itself says 'If more than one event rule applies to a particular event or metric' that means we are considering more than one event rule here and the order of execution is from low to high in that case.

Selected Answer: B
In Utah we need to mark the ""Apply additional matching rules" checkbox to execute additional rules based on order

Selected Answer: C
Since Tokyo release the correct answer is C
It's a crappy question, either B or C "could" be correct...it all depends on how the "Apply additional matching rules" field on those event rules is set.

I know the blueprint answer. but the video (time stamp 59 seconds) in the link below states, "only the event rule with the lowest order will run."
https://docs.servicenow.com/en-US/bundle/utah-it-operations-management/page/product/event-management/concept/create-event-rules.html
C. All event rules will run, from the lowest to the highest Order of execution numbers.

Selected Answer: D
less complexity and maintenance

Selected Answer: C
Determine if for events without a matching rule you really need to handle this with a rule or not.

comments.content: do you have any documentation for this answer

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
It is good practice to cover more events with less rules.

C
See "em_event.state" in
https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/washingtondc-it-operations-management/page/product/event-management/concept/c_EMIntegrateRequirementEvent.html

C
